div.p:
Narrator:
A family history of alcoholism creating increased risk. Psychological and social factors influencing high-risk choices. High tolerance creating a false sense of strength. Powerful elements blending into a perfect storm of high-risk choices.

Armando:
I started drinking when I was about 12 or 13. And the first time that I got drunk we were in a party. It was a wonderful experience because it felt like it was a vehicle to make me feel part of the crowd. Alcohol is ok because my mom, my uncles, everybody drinks, when every role model around you that's around you drinks, it's just so normal like learning how to eat or drink water.

Narrator:
Armando moved to the United States and he met his wife shortly thereafter.

Armando:
I think she thought that I married that great guy. Of course until I started getting drunk, she saw the other part.

Ezdeyna:
I mainly remember him being abusive to his wife. And I used to think oh, I hope he doesn't hurt her. You just knew on his look when he turned. He was getting to that point that you just wanted to hide or not be around during that situation.

Narrator:
Heavy drinking made Armando unavailable to his sister, who desperately needed his love and help. Ezdeyna was living with their mother, whose own alcoholism had triggered violent behavior.

Ezdeyna:
I was 11 years old and um, he had gotten drunk. He was laying on the sofa and I said, you need to help me, you need to get me out of this situation. I kept saying Armando help me, you know. And all he could do was just say, I can't, I can't do anything.

Narrator:
Ezdeyna was forced into foster care because Armando was unable to protect her from their violent mother. Meanwhile, Armando's drinking got him in constant trouble with the law.

Armando:
I got many DUIs, that didn't stop me from driving. I thought at the time that I was a better driver when I was drunk. So I was driving and I saw the sirens and the lights, and why are they stopping me for?

Narrator:
Unconcerned about others' safety, or his own, Armando began a bizarre and dangerous driving practice.

Armando:
Many times when I was drunk, I drove with children in the car, and I thought that everybody was going to be happy if I did something funny, so I thought that driving with the lights off was funny...when I was drunk.

Ezdeyna:
He just all the sudden turned off the lights of the car, and we weren't even wearing seat belts. And he was just driving around in the dark you know, laughing.

Armando:
And I thought it was very funny. I thought it was funny! It scares me that I did that. I cannot believe that I would put people in danger in that way.

Ezdeyna:
I just couldn't wait to go home at that time. And I stopped visiting him after that.

Narrator:
Heavy drinking provoked extreme personality changes. Armando's family feared him and never knew from moment to moment what, or who, to expect.

Armando:
There was a huge difference in my behavior and my thoughts and my actions when I was not drinking than, compared to when I was drinking.

Glenda:
Most of what I had fear constantly with him is the fact that when he was drinking he was a whole different person.

Armando:
My kids they would say, Dad we knew that something was wrong, that was not you, that's what they said. We knew when it was not you by the look.

Glenda:
It was always something with him.

Ezdeyna:
Everything angered him, everything bothered him.

Glenda:
He really was another person.

Armando:
Kind of like mad, and then I started getting angry, and I became extremely abusive.

Glenda:
I don't think most people would remember much when they're like 3 or 4 years old, but I think when you see enough bad you remember.

Armando:
And I would be very mean, like a monster, horrible.

Glenda:
He'd get home and I can just remember him yelling and...I don't even remember over what but it was always just the constant yelling towards my mom. She would just kind of sit there, it's almost as if she was used to it.

Armando:
I was horrible in a sense. I would mistreat them, put them down, make them feel bad.

Glenda:
And half the time it would end with him beating her.

Narrator:
Because of the family history, Glenda has an increased biological risk for alcoholism and drug addiction.

Glenda:
When I started drinking, it was to kinda tune him out most of the time. It was my escape, which I when I look back now, what kind of escape is that. Probably would have ended up like him.

Narrator:
She struggles sometimes, but vivid memories from the past help steer her away from making high-risk choices to deal with the bad times.

Glenda:
I was little and I just remember he was hitting her and I ran and jumped on his back and I was like stop, and he just threw me as if I was a dog, just throw me.

Armando:
Why did I want them to suffer, it wasn't me.

Narrator:
Today, Armando still struggles with the results of his high-risk behavior. He's been to jail, lost countless jobs and a chance to go to college, and spent untold sums trying to salvage his life. But it's the emotional losses that Armando has the most trouble coming to grips with.

Ezdeyna:
My brother lost many good relationships, with his children, with me.

Armando:
She spent 10 years in the foster care system, with no brothers or sisters or mom or dad.

Ezdeyna:
I think that if he was better, or he wasn't an alcoholic, he could have taken care of me.

Armando:
And I couldn't take her with me because I was drunk, I was dangerous to her. So I think she resents that a lot.

Ezdeyna:
You almost feel abandoned.

Armando:
And my oldest daughter, I cannot even begin to enumerate many times that I was mean to her.

Glenda:
I think he's lost a portion of my life that he is trying to get to know now, not that it's too late but in a sense, it is.

Ezdeyna:
I don't think that any normal child should go through any of these experiences, because the trauma never goes away.

Glenda:
There's always been love but the, it's mostly the security that I didn't have from him.

Ezdeyna:
It affects everybody in your family. Everybody.

Armando:
All the things that I lost that were important to me, I did it by the age of 23. I didn't have to grow up to be 40, 30, 50. By the age of 23, I lost everything.
